meanings.definition: To concentrate on a particular point or area
meanings.sent1: She tried to focalise on her homework despite the noise around her.
meanings.sent2: He needed to focalise on the task at hand to complete it on time.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to focalise on catching the elusive red dot.
meanings.sent4: Her mind began to focalise on the upcoming exam like a laser beam.
meanings.sent5: The teacher asked the students to focalise on the main idea of the story.

meanings.definition: To adjust a lens or optical instrument to focus on a specific object
meanings.sent1: He carefully focalised the camera to capture the beautiful sunset.
meanings.sent2: The photographer needed to focalise the lens to take a clear picture.
meanings.sent3: The curious child tried to focalise the binoculars on a distant bird.
meanings.sent4: She quickly focalised the microscope to see the tiny details of the specimen.
meanings.sent5: The astronomer had to focalise the telescope to observe the distant stars.

meanings.definition: To make something the center of attention or interest
meanings.sent1: The new exhibit aimed to focalise visitors' attention on ancient artifacts.
meanings.sent2: The speaker tried to focalise the audience's interest on the importance of recycling.
meanings.sent3: The magician used a trick to focalise the audience's attention on the disappearing coin.
meanings.sent4: Her colorful outfit focalised everyone's attention at the party.
meanings.sent5: The headline was designed to focalise readers' interest on the breaking news.
